Passivity vs. activity
7. Passivity vs. activity

Hyletic data are arguably experiences, in the sense of
“non-intentional”, “pre-reflective lived experiences
that can be grasped only abstractly in reflection” (Gallagher
2011, p. 3). At the same time, at least some of them (the
“kinaesthetic” sensations; cf. Zahavi 2003, p. 107) belong
to the sphere of bodily passivity: they “serve in the
constitution of the experiencing body (the body-as-subject)”
(Gallagher 2011, p. 4; for the distinction between
“body-as-subject” and “body-as-object”, cf.
Zahavi 2003, pp. 101–106). The notion of passivity is given
particular emphasis both in the context of Husserl’s
genetic-phenomenological analyses, focussing on the dynamic aspects of
self- and object-constitution, and in his reply to the
“objection of solipsism” against transcendental
phenomenology developed in the 5th of his Cartesian
Meditations (see Section 10 below). In Experience and
Judgement Husserl stresses “that the
distinction between activity and passivity is not a rigid one, that it
cannot be a matter of terms that can be defined once and for all, but
only of means of description and contrast, the meaning of which must
originally be recreated in each individual case with regard to the
concrete situation of the analysis” (Husserl 1939, p. 119). On a
plausible (i.e., epistemological) interpretation, a unit of
consciousness in which something constitutes itself is to be described
as “passive” just in case this constitution occurs
independently of any simultaneous execution of the subject’s
will, e.g., its will to acquire knowledge; otherwise, it is to be
described as “active”. Passive constitution is sometimes
referred to as “pre-constitution”, as it is an
indispensible precondition for active constitution (cf. Landgrebe
1982b, p. 72.) According to the above interpretation, active
constitution in the form of judgements in turn initiates beliefs as
personal “acquisitions (Erwerbe)” or
“habitualities” that help pre-constitute the further
course of experience, thus forming a “secondary” level of
passivity (cf. ibid.; for an overview of Husserl’s
“phenomenology of habituality” cf. Moran 2011; Caminada
2019 investigates into Husserl’s view of habit against the
background of the re-edition of Ideas II on the basis of his
original texts; see esp. ch. 10f). 

In the context of the analysis of the constitution of individual
perceptual objects, the spatio-temporally structured “field of
pre-givenness” (Husserl 1939, p. 74) against whose background
the object stands out contrastively (ready to catch the
perceiver’s attention) counts as primarily passive (cf. Wu 2021,
sec. 58). This field is structured by “syntheses of
association” between (hyletic adumbrations of) similar and
dissimilar elements (cf. Wu 2020, p. 189). These associative syntheses
are such that (in the case at issue) one of those elements, e.g. a
colored three-dimensional (and thus non-hyletic; cf. Lee 1993, p. 99)
dot, serves as sensual “stimulus” by “instinctively
driving” (Husserliana Mat., vol. VIII, p. 326) the
perceiver to attend to it unwillingly, thus passively
“affecting” the perceiver (Husserliana, vol.
XXXIII, pp. 275f; cf. Yamaguchi 1982; Lee 1993; also cf. Mensch 1997;
and Brudzinska 2020, containing a detailed comparison with Freud). If
the stimulus then catches the subject’s attention, it can
subsequently be “explicated” perceptually according to its
objectual determinations, in which case the subject enters “the
first main stage of the striving for knowledge, i.e. the
pre-predicative or receptive stage” (Wu 2021, p.
190). Thus, passivity precedes receptivity, which in turn precedes the
second main stage, i.e. the “predicative” stage –
the level of the “spontaneity” of judgement (cf. Wu 2021,
p. 191). Both of these stages (the receptive and the spontaneous one)
constitute the level of cognitive “activity”. At the
second stage, the processing of mental files such as “individual
notions” (see Section 4 above), guided by the subject’s
“will to knowledge” (Husserl 1939, p. 92), is located. In
Experience and Judgement Husserl calls the
perceptual acts motivating predicative file entries (i.e., habitual
yet variable empirical beliefs) “explications” of
perceptual objects (cf. Husserl 1939, ch. 2). Such explications are
founded in “attention as a tendency of the ego”
“toward the intentional object” (Husserl 1939, p. 85).
(For the multifarious use of the term “attention” in
Husserl cf. the introduction to Husserliana, vol. XXXVIII, p.
XXXII; see also the entry on “Aufmerksamkeit” in Gander
2010, pp. 36ff, and the secondary literature cited there, as well as
Breyer 2011, ch. V, and Wehrle 2013, ch. I.)

Note that while Husserl sometimes describes the field of pre-givenness
in which pre-predicative and predicative acts are founded as
“originarily passive” (cf. Husserl 1939, p. 300), he holds
that this field is itself pre-constituted at an even more basic level
of constitution, also sometimes (in another context) described as
originarily or primarily passive. This more basic level is the
“absolutely” originary one of (1) bodily and (2) temporal
pre-reflective self-consciousness, at which (1) the spatial and (2)
the temporal aspects of the field, respectively, constitute themselves
(cf. Wu 2021, pp. 187f). This pre-constitution occurs automatically or
“instinctively”, by “association” of
“acquired” affective “drives” and
teleologically directed “courses of drives
(Triebverläufe)” rather than mere “(courses
of) ideas”, such that “the ego as the subject of the drive
[…] is awakened” (transcr. A VII 13, p. 20, cited after
Yamaguchi 1982, p. 57). If the subject then acquires an according
affective “habituality”, then a new level of
“secondary passivity” has been constituted (cf. Yamaguchi
1982, p. 56). For example, the above-mentioned colored dot is then
ready to be perceived as located, at ‘this current moment’
of (internal) time, at ‘that position’ in ‘my
own’ (egocentric) perceptual field; it “affects” the
subject accordingly, thus serving as a visual stimulus. This
perceptual field is regarded as ‘my own’ and ‘my
current’ one in virtue of its pre-constitution in pre-reflective
self-awareness, in which both the subject’s stream of
consciousness and its living body (as it would appear in the
“sphere of ownness”, i.e. independently of intersubjective
experience) constitute themselves, notably by both internal
time-consciousness (see Sections 4 and 6 above; cf. Held 1966) and the
instinctive “originary kinestheses” (Husserliana,
vol. XV, p. 385) or “kinesthetic syntheses” associated
with the bodily movements involved in perception (cf. Landgrebe 1982b,
pp. 81 ff; also cf. Dodd 1997 for a further analysis of
Husserl’s phenomenology of the body, taking into account the
rich material to be found in Ideas II, but also in Thing
and Space and the 5th of the Cartesian
Meditations; and Taipale 2014, stressing the importance of the
living body for the different levels of constitution in Husserl; more
recent literature on embodiment in Husserl, covering topics like the
constitution of the ego’s own living body and the living bodies of
others, also includes Behnke 1996; Heinämaa 2011, 2018; Moran and
Janssen, eds., 2018; Carr 2019; and Jardine 2022, ch. 5f).

On (one reading of) Husserl’s view, these very basic levels or
strata underlying self- and world-constitution are still
“anonymous”, i.e. not available through
(self-)“reflection” (cf. Landgrebe 1982b, p. 76), but only
through the “genetic-phenomenological” method of
“deconstruction” or “dismantling
(Abbau)”. Dismantling starts from a given noematic
sense, like ‘this coloured dot’, and tells a story about
how (the intentionality correlated with) this sense could have come
about, to which kinds of “subjective sources” or origins
it implicitly refers back (as their “sedimentation”),
given the transcendental conditions for the possibility of the
corresponding forms of intentionality (cf. Husserl 1939, p. 47). This
dismantling leads back to the associative “originary
pairing” of ‘my own’, originarily-kinesthetic
pre-constituted living body, on the one hand, and a foreign one
affecting ‘my own’, on the other, due to similarities
which passively drive the “first ‘ego’ of the
reduction” (Husserliana, vol. XV, p. 586) to
co-constitute ‘my own’ and the ‘other’ bodily
ego by accordingly motivated “apperceptive transfer”
(Husserliana, vol. I, 140) of the pre-constituted sense
‘this living body of mine’ to the similarly behaving body
‘over there’ (cf. A. D. Smith 2003, pp. 224–251).
This co-constitution forms the basis of, first, the co-constitution of
the alter ego as a personal human being and (on this basis; cf.
Husserliana, vol. XIV, p. 418) myself as the same kind of
being and, secondly, the constitution objective reality. The (analysis
of the) constitution of the latter is sketched in Section 10 below.
Husserl supposes that its passive pre-constitution
“‘instinctively’ predeliniates the constitution of
the whole world for me”, a teleological “facticity”
perhaps deriving from “God” (Husserliana, vol.
XV, p. 385; see Held 2010). (In other words, the spade bends back
here.)
